text: Ahaz was twenty years old when he began to reign, and he reigned for sixteen years in Jerusalem. He did not do what pleased the Lord, in contrast to his ancestor David.

He <st data-num="01980" class="">followed</st> in the <st data-num="01870" class="">footsteps</st> of<n id="1" /> the <st data-num="04428" class="">kings</st> of <st data-num="03478" class="">Israel</st>; he <st data-num="01571" class="">also</st> <st data-num="06213" class="">made</st> <st data-num="04541" class="">images</st> of the <st data-num="01168" class="">Baals</st>.
He offered sacrifices in the Valley of Ben Hinnom and passed his sons through the fire, a horrible sin practiced by the nations whom the Lord drove out before the Israelites.
He offered sacrifices and burned incense on the high places, on the hills, and under every green tree.
The Lord his God handed him over to the king of Syria. The Syrians defeated him and deported many captives to Damascus. He was also handed over to the king of Israel, who thoroughly defeated him.
In one day Pekah son of Remaliah killed 120,000 warriors in Judah because they had abandoned the Lord God of their ancestors.

<st data-num="02147" class="">Zikri</st>, an <st data-num="0669" class="">Ephraimite</st> <st data-num="01368" class="">warrior</st>, <st data-num="02026" class="">killed</st> the <st data-num="04428" class="">king’s</st> <st data-num="01121" class="">son</st> <st data-num="04641" class="">Maaseiah</st>, <st data-num="05840" class="">Azrikam</st>, the <st data-num="05057" class="">supervisor</st> of the <st data-num="01004" class="">palace</st>, and <st data-num="0511" class="">Elkanah</st>, the <st data-num="04428" class="">king’s</st> <st data-num="04932" class="">second-in-command</st>.
The Israelites seized from their brothers 200,000 wives, sons, and daughters. They also carried off a huge amount of plunder and took it back to Samaria.

Oded, a prophet of the Lord, was there. He went to meet the army as they arrived in Samaria and said to them: “Look, because the Lord God of your ancestors was angry with Judah, he handed them over to you. You have killed them so mercilessly that God has taken notice.
And now you are planning to enslave the people of Judah and Jerusalem. Yet are you not also guilty before the Lord your God?
Now listen to me! Send back those you have seized from your brothers, for the Lord is very angry at you!”

So <st data-num="0376" class="">some</st> of<n id="1" /> the <st data-num="0669" class="">Ephraimite</st> <st data-num="01121" class="">family</st> <st data-num="07218" class="">leaders</st>, <st data-num="05838" class="">Azariah</st> <st data-num="01121" class="">son</st> of <st data-num="03076" class="">Jehochanan</st>, <st data-num="01296" class="">Berechiah</st> <st data-num="01121" class="">son</st> of <st data-num="04919" class="">Meshillemoth</st>, <st data-num="03169" class="">Jechizkiah</st> <st data-num="01121" class="">son</st> of <st data-num="07967" class="">Shallum</st>, and <st data-num="06021" class="">Amasa</st> <st data-num="01121" class="">son</st> of <st data-num="02311" class="">Hadlai</st> <st data-num="06965 05921">confronted</st><n id="2" /> those <st data-num="0935" class="">returning</st> <st data-num="04480" class="">from</st> the <st data-num="06635" class="">battle</st>.
They said to them, “Don’t bring those captives here! Are you planning on making us even more sinful and guilty before the Lord? Our guilt is already great, and the Lord is very angry at Israel.”

So the <st data-num="02502" class="">soldiers</st> <st data-num="05800" class="">released</st> the <st data-num="07633" class="">captives</st> and the <st data-num="0961" class="">plunder</st> <st data-num="06440" class="">before</st> the <st data-num="08269" class="">officials</st> and the <st data-num="03605" class="">entire</st> <st data-num="06951" class="">assembly</st>.

Men were assigned to take the prisoners and find clothes among the plunder for those who were naked. So they clothed them, supplied them with sandals, gave them food and drink, and provided them with oil to rub on their skin. They put the ones who couldn’t walk on donkeys. They brought them back to their brothers at Jericho, the city of date palm trees, and then returned to Samaria.
At that time King Ahaz asked the king of Assyria for help.

The <st data-num="0130" class="">Edomites</st> had <st data-num="05750" class="">again</st> <st data-num="0935" class="">invaded</st> and <st data-num="05221" class="">defeated</st> <st data-num="03063" class="">Judah</st> and <st data-num="07617" class="">carried off</st> <st data-num="07628" class="">captives</st>.

The <st data-num="06430" class="">Philistines</st> had <st data-num="06584" class="">raided</st> the <st data-num="05892" class="">cities</st> of <st data-num="03063" class="">Judah</st> in the <st data-num="08219" class="">foothills</st><n id="1" /> and the <st data-num="05045" class="">Negev</st>.<n id="2" /> They <st data-num="03920" class="">captured</st> and <st data-num="03427 08033">settled</st> in <st data-num="01053" class="">Beth Shemesh</st>, <st data-num="0357" class="">Aijalon</st>, <st data-num="01450" class="">Gederoth</st>, <st data-num="07755" class="">Soco</st> and its <st data-num="01323" class="">surrounding villages</st>, <st data-num="08553" class="">Timnah</st> and its <st data-num="01323" class="">surrounding villages</st>, and <st data-num="01579" class="">Gimzo</st> and its <st data-num="01323" class="">surrounding villages</st>.
The Lord humiliated Judah because of King Ahaz of Israel, for he encouraged Judah to sin and was very unfaithful to the Lord.

<st data-num="04428" class="">King</st> <st data-num="08407" class="">Tiglath-Pileser</st><n id="1" /> of <st data-num="0804" class="">Assyria</st> <st data-num="0935 05921">came</st>, but he <st data-num="06696" class="">gave</st> him more <st data-num="06696" class="">trouble</st> <st data-num="03808" class="">than</st> <st data-num="02388" class="">support</st>.<n id="2" />
Ahaz gathered riches from the Lord’s temple, the royal palace, and the officials and gave them to the king of Assyria, but that did not help.
During his time of trouble King Ahaz was even more unfaithful to the Lord.

He <st data-num="02076" class="">offered sacrifices</st> to the <st data-num="0430" class="">gods</st> of <st data-num="01834" class="">Damascus</st> whom he thought had <st data-num="05221" class="">defeated</st> him.<n id="1" /> He <st data-num="0559" class="">reasoned</st>,<n id="2" /> “<st data-num="03588" class="">Since</st> the <st data-num="0430" class="">gods</st> of the <st data-num="04428" class="">kings</st> of <st data-num="0758" class="">Syria</st> <st data-num="01992 05826">helped</st> them, I will <st data-num="02076" class="">sacrifice</st> to them so they will <st data-num="05826" class="">help</st> me.” But <st data-num="01992" class="">they</st> <st data-num="01961" class="">caused</st> him and <st data-num="03605" class="">all</st> <st data-num="03478" class="">Israel</st> to <st data-num="03782" class="">stumble</st>.
Ahaz gathered the items in God’s temple and removed them. He shut the doors of the Lord’s temple and erected altars on every street corner in Jerusalem.
In every city throughout Judah he set up high places to offer sacrifices to other gods. He angered the Lord God of his ancestors.
The rest of the events of Ahaz’s reign, including his accomplishments from start to finish, are recorded in the Scroll of the Kings of Judah and Israel.
Ahaz passed away and was buried in the city of Jerusalem; they did not bring him to the tombs of the kings of Israel. His son Hezekiah replaced him as king.
